Introduction to Esports
Module 2: Benefits of an Esports Program

Social Skills

“Esports takes a massive amount of communication and coordination amongst athletes. It allows for a deeper level of interaction and trains efficient communication. These skills honed in gameplay readies students for life.”

- High School Esports League (HSEL);
mentioned in How to Start a High School Esports Team

Gaming is often a solitary activity and students who enjoy gaming are often those who are less involved in school activities. Competitive esports provides a way for like-minded students to meet in person on a regular basis, in pursuit of common goals – providing a sense of belonging for those who might otherwise opt out of school activities. As a scheduled school activity, esports clubs provide the opportunity to form friendships, gain respect from fellow students and increased self-esteem. [https://massp.com/esports]

For example, AnyKey.org suggests the following pledge for esports competitors:

I pledge to:

  • Be a good sport whether I win or lose.
  • Remember that people online are still real people.
  • Know that my actions and words can have real impact.
  • Speak up against hate speech, harassment, abuse, and assault of any kind.
  • Show integrity by respecting the rules, opponents, and teammates.
  • Stop, listen, and reassess if I'm told that my words or actions are harmful.
  • Respect the sincere opinions of others, even if they’re different from mine.

Like many high school clubs and sports, esports helps students learn valuable skills that will serve them well throughout their life. Among the skills developed through esports are strategic thinking, teamwork, collaboration, goal setting, preparation, and managing success and failure. Many students are already passionate about gaming. Esports provides an opportunity for students to come together and bond over a shared interest.

Esports also encourages students who compete in these intense and fast-paced, real-time strategy games to quickly problem-solve and adapt to win. Players are required to set goals, assess the competition, and evaluate their own strengths and weaknesses. As a team member, students learn to establish tactics, create game plans, and pivot as needed.
